content: IntroductionDiscret em olecular architectu res[1¨C2]hold the attention ofre-searche rsforawiderange ofapplications ingas storag e,mo-lecular recogniti on,catalysis, and drug delivery .Overthepastthree decade s,numerou smolecu lararchit ectures[3]have beendevelop edbyalterin gsuitabl eorganic space rsand metalcounter parts. However ,analogous organic molecu larassem-blies arehardtoachieve byusing traditi onal multistep organicsynthe sis,which generally leads tolow yield ofthefinal prod-ucts. Ther efore, dynam iccovale ntchemistr y(DCC) hasbeen in-troduc edasanefficient altern ativeapproac htoharvest organ-iccage compounds[4]from simple buildin gblocks. Inthisregard, our group has recent lyreported severa lfunctionalizedorganic cages byusing dynamic imine chemistry .Such cagesshowe dpotentia lapplications[5]inexplosives sens ing and incatalys is.Although consid erable efforts inrecent times havebeen direct edtothesynthesis ofseveral organic cage com-pounds ofvarious sizesand shapes, examples oforganic mo-lecular barrel s[6]obtained byusing dynamic covalen tbonds arestillrare. The barrel structure has several benef itsowing toitsporou sconfined space. Furth ermo re,the two open faces ofthe barrel can beused asentry and exit windo wsforsub-strates andproducts ,respectivel y.The present article reportsanunusual example ofanorganic tetrafa cialmolecu larbarrel(OB4R)includi ngitsuse asapotential molec ular vessel forthesynth esisofsilver nanop articles (/C251.44 nm).[14]Magnetic, optoel ectron ic,and medicinal properties ofmetalnanop articles (MNPs) have been widel yused forvarious pur-poses.[7]Owingtotheir high surface area/volum eratio with anumber ofunsaturation sites, tiny MNPs areoften preferr edover the bulk metal precu rsors incatalysis.[8]Moreover ,MNPshave drawn special attention inphoto catalysis owing totheirlocalized surfac eplasmon resonan ce(LSPR) effect.[9]This effectmainly implies the collective resonanc ebetween conductionband electrons with incide ntlight, which mostlygenerat esholes and hot electr ons (h¨Ce) ontheMNP surface.[10]Thus, ul-trafin eMNPs promote photocatalytic reactio nsowing totheLSPR effect, which isthermodyna mically not feasible intheground state.[11]Inthis respect, silver nanop articles (AgNP s)areappeal ingowing totheir LSPR effectinthevisible light region(400¨C 800nm).[12]Moreov er,photocatalyt icroutes under visiblelight are often lesstoxic, involves less energy consu mption,and aremore eco-fri endly comp ared withconventiona lwet-chem icalmethods. Therefore, toprepar etinyMNPs ofvarioussizes, several supp ort materials suchaspolymers ,[13]metaloxides,[14]metal ¨Corga nic frameworks,[15]andcovalent-o rganicframe works[16]have been well documente d.The key problems[a]B.Mondal, P.Bhandar i,Prof. P.S.MukherjeeDepar tment ofInorg anic and Physica lChemi stryIndian Institute ofScienceBangalo re56001 2(India)E-mail :psm@ iisc.ac.inSuppo rting informa tion and theORCID identifica tion number(s) fortheautho r(s)ofthisarticl ecanbefound under :https ://doi .org/10.10 02/che m.202003390 .
Department of Inorganic and Physical Chemistry, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India.  E-mail: psm@iisc.ac .in. Fax: 91 -80-2360 -1552; Tel; 91 -80-2293 -3352 .

Synthe sisoftheorgan icbarrel OB4Am ethanolic solution (50mL) of diamine EA (12.15 mg,0.202 mmol) was added dropwise toasolution ofaldehyde TA(50.0 mg, 0.101 mmol) inCHCl3(150 mL). The reaction mixture waskept undisturbed atroom temperature foraweek. After comple-tion ofthe reaction, aslight amount ofwhite insoluble productwas observed onthevessel wall. The reaction mixture was filteredtoobtain aclear colorless solution and then thefiltrate was con-centrated under reduced pressure. Cold n-pentane was added toitslowly toobtain the product asawhite precipitate, which waswashed with CH3OHseveral times and dried under vacuum for6h.

Synthesis oftheorganic barrel OB4ROB4 (50.2 mg, 0.0231 mmol) was taken inCHCl3/MeOH (160 mL,1:1,v/v) solvent mixture. NaBH4(28.1 mg, 0.74 mmol) was addedportion-wise totheabove mixture atroom temperature and wasstirred for1day.Thesolvent was removed after thecompletion ofthe reaction, and the product was extracted inCHCl3(50mL/C1483).

The organic part was washed several times with water and driedover anhydrous Na2SO4followed byremoval ofsolvents toobtainOB4Rasaw hite powder .Isolated yield :87.13 %( 44.4 mg,0.02015 mmol).1HNMR(500 MHz, CDCl3):d=7.59 (d,32H),7.49 (s,8H),7.23 (d,32H),4.09 (d,32H),2.80¨C2.75 ppm (m,32H);13CNMRFigure 5.(a)Reusability plot ofAg0@OB4R(yield sofcrude products arecal-culate dby1HNMRanalysis) ,(b)PXRD plot ofrecycle dAg0@OB4Rafter fivecycles .

Synthesis ofbarrel-supported silver nanoparticles Ag0@OB4ROB4R(20.1 mg, 0.0091 mmol) dissolved inCHCl3(6mL;colorless)was treated with aCH3OH(3mL) solution ofCF3SO3Ag(56.26 mg,0.2189 mmol ;colorless) and stirred for1hatroom temperature.

Into this reaction mixture (yellow colored), amethanolic solution(1mL) ofNaBH4(16.64 mg, 0.4379 mmol) was added dropwise atroom temperature and stirred for1h(black colored). The solutionwas centrifuged and the product was washed several times withmethanol followed byvacuum drying for12htoobtain Ag0@OB4Rasablack solid powder .

Gener alprocedure forUllman-type coupling ofhaloare nesStandard method fortheUllman-type coupling reaction of4-bro-mobenzaldehyde byusing Ag0@OB4R:A25mLquartz tube wascharged with 4-bromobenzaldehyde (185 mg, 1mmol), imidazole(102.1 1mg,1.5mmol), K2CO3(276.41 mg, 2mmol), and Ag0@OB4R(2.074 mg, 1mol%ofAg,1.12 wt%)along with drydimethyl for-mamide (5mL). Subsequently ,themixture was degassed under ni-trogen atmosphere and stirred for10hunder visible light irradia-tion at30 8C.The reaction tube was taken outfrom theUVcham-ber and the mixture was filtered toseparate the solid catalystAg0@OB4R.Thecatalyst was washed several times properly withwater and ethyl acetate and dried invacuum (12h)forthe nextcycle. The organic layer was washed with water vigorously anddried over anhydrous Na2SO4followed bycomplete removal ofthesolvent under reduced pressure. The crude mass was purified withaneutral alumina column using n-hexane/ethyl acetate (1:1,v/v) toafford pure 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzaldehyde asayellowish crys-talline solid (94%yield, 162.1 mg).1HNMR(CDCl3,400MHz): d=10.04 (s,1H),8.02 (d,2H),7.97 (s,1H),7.58 (d,2H),7.37 (s,1H),7.26 ppm (s,1H);13CNMR(100 MHz, CDCl3):d=190.6, 141.8, 135.5,135.1, 131.7, 131.4, 121.2, 117.7ppm. For 1mmol offluoro-,chloro-, and iodo-substrates, the product yields were 124.1 mg(72%),143.0 mg (83%),and 161.9 mg (94%),respectively .Yieldsand NMR data ofother catalytic products arereported intheSup-porting Information.

Synthesis of Tetra-aldehyde TA: In a 250 mL two -neck round -bottom flask, 2 g (5.08 mmol) of 1, 2, 4, 5-tetrabromobenzene and 4.57 g (30.48 mmol) of 4 -formylphenylboronic acid were taken in 1 50 mL THF and into that 30-mL aqueous solution of 5.6 g (40.64 mmol) K 2CO 3 was added. The resulting mixture was degassed under nitrogen atmosphere. After coming to roo m temperature, 294 mg (5 m ol%) of catalyst Pd(PPh 3)4 was added to the mixture and heated to 70¡ãC for 48h. After completion of the reaction , the solvents  were removed under reduced pressure and the crude part was extracted with dichloromethane (100 mL ? 3). Organic part was then dried over anhydrous Na 2SO 4 under reduced pressure to obtain crude solid. The crude solid was further  S3 purified by silica gel column chromatography in dichloromethane/hexane  (2:1)  mixture to obtain compound  TA as white powder. Isolated yield: 8 3.98% (2.11 g, 4.2 66 mmol). 1H NMR ( 500 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 9.99 (s, 4H), 7.79 (d, 8H), 7.60 (s, 2H), 7.39 (d, 8H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 191.8, 146.2, 139.6, 135.2, 132.9, 130.5, 129.8. ESI -HRMS (CHCl 3-CH 3OH): m/z for C 34H22O4: [M+H]+ 495.1579 (calcd 495.1596). FT-IR (cm?1): v 1693 (C=O).

Synthesis of Imine Organic Barrel OB4 : In a 250 mL round bottom flask 50 mL MeOH solution of diamine EA (12.15 mg, 0.202 mmol) was added slowly dropwise to a clear solution of aldehyde TA (50.0 mg, 0.101 mmol) dissolved in 150 mL CHCl 3. The resulting reaction mixture was kept still at room temperature for 7 days. After completion of the reaction, a slight amount o f white insoluble product was observed  on the walls . The reaction mixture was filtered to obtain a clear colorless solution and then filtrate was reduced to concentrate  under pressure . Cold n -pentane was added to it slowly  which gave a white precipitate. T he precipitate was washed with CH 3OH several times and dried under vacuum for 6h. Isolated yield: 62. 33 % (34.2 mg, 0.015 7 mmol). 1H NMR ( 500 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 8.24 (s, 16H), 7.56 (d, 32H), 7.49 (s, 8H), 7.21 (d, 32H), 3.61 -3.63 (m, 16H), 2.96 -2.98 (m, 16H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 160.5, 139.2, 135.7, 130.8, 128.6, 122.0, 118.3, 21.6. ESI -HRMS (CHCl 3-CH 3OH): m/z for C 152H120N16: [M+H]+ 2171.0023 (calcd 2170.9994), [M+2H]2+ 1085.9973 (calcd 1086.0036). FT-IR (cm?1): v 1644 (C= N).

Synthesis of Amine Organi c Barrel OB4R: In a 250 mL round bottom flask  50.2 mg (0.0231 mmol) of OB4  was taken in 160 mL CHCl 3-MeOH (1:1, v/v) binary solvent mixture. Into above reaction mixture, 28.1 mg (0.74 mmol) of NaBH 4 was added portion wise at room temperature and stirred for 1 day. After completion of the reaction, solvent was completely removed, and the product was extracted in CHCl 3 (50 X 3) . Organic part was washed several times with water and dried over anhydrous Na2SO 4 followed by removal of solvent to obtain OB4R as  S4 white powder. Isolated yield: 87. 13% (44.4 mg, 0.0201 5 mmol). 1H NMR ( 500 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 7.59 (d, 32H), 7.49 (s, 8H), 7.23 (d, 32H), 4.09 (d, 32H), 2.75 -2.80 (m, 32H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 141. 8, 136.1, 132.8, 130.6, 120.8, 117.8, 24.9, 19.9. ESI -HRMS (CHCl 3-CH 3OH): m/z for C 152H152N16: [M+H]+ 2203.2424 (calcd 2203.2498), [M+2H]2+ 1102.1269 (calcd 1102.1288).

Synthesis of Barrel Supported Silver Nanoparticles Ag(0)@OB4R: In a typical synthesis procedure, 20.1 mg (0.009 1 mmol) of OB4R dissolved in 6 mL CHCl 3 (colorless) was treated with 3 mL CH 3OH solution of 5 6.26 mg (0.2 189 mmol) of CF 3SO 3Ag (colorless) and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Into this reaction mixture (yellow colored), 1 mL methanolic solution of NaBH 4 (16.64 mg, 0.4 379 mmol) was added dropwise at room temperature and stirred for 1h (black colored). After th e mentioned  time, the solution was centrifuged to precipitate down.
The product was washed several times with methanol followed by drying under vacuum for 12  h to obtain Ag(0)@OB4R as black solid powder.

Ullmann -type aryl -amination coupling reaction :  General Procedure for Ullman -type Coupling of Haloarenes:  Standard  method for the Ullman -type coupling reaction of 4 -bromobenzaldehyde using Ag(0)@OB4R: A 25 mL quartz tube charged with 185 mg (1 mmol) of 4 -bromobenzaldehyde, 102.11 mg (1.5 mmol) of imidazole, 276. 41 mg (2 mmol) of K 2CO 3 and 2. 074 mg (1 mol%  of Ag , 1.12 wt%) of Ag(0)@OB4R along with 5 mL dry DMF . Subsequently, the mixture was degassed under nitrogen atmosphere and stirred for 10 h under visible light irradiation at 30oC. After this time period the reaction tube w as taken out from UV chamber and the mixture was filtered to separate the solid catalys t Ag(0)@OB4R. The catalyst was washed several times properly with water and ethyl acetate and dried in vacuum (12  h) for next cycle use. Next, ethyl acetate was used to extract the filtrate (100 mL ? 3). The organic layer was washed with water vigorously a nd dried over anhydrous Na 2SO 4 followed by complete removal of solvent under reduced pressure. The crude mass was purified by neutral alumina column using hexane/ethyl acetate (1:1, v/v) to afford pure 4 -(1H-imidazol -1-yl)benzaldehyde as yellowish crystall ine solid.

94% yield (162.1 mg). 1H NMR (CDCl 3, 400 MHz): ¦Ä 10.04 (s, 1H), 8.02 (d, 2H), 7.97 (s, 1H), 7.58 (2H), 7.37 (s, 1H), 7.26 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 190.6, 141.8, 135.5, 135.1, 131.7, 131.4, 121.2, 117.7. For 1 mmol of fluoro, chloro -  S23 and iodo -substrates, product yields were 124.1 mg (72%), 14 3.0 mg (83%) and 161. 9 mg (94%), respectively.

1,3,5 -tri(1H -imidazol -1-yl)benzene:  76% yield (210.2 mg); white crystalline solid; 1H NMR (DMSO -D6, 400 MHz): ¦Ä 8.55 (s, 3H), 8. 04 (s, 3H), 7.96 (s, 3H), 7.19 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO -D6): ¦Ä 139.1, 136.1, 130.1, 118.3, 109.3.[1a]    1,2,4,5 -tetra(1H -imidazol -1-yl)benzene:  63% yield (216 .0 mg); white crystalline solid; 1H NMR (MeOH -D4, 400 MHz): ¦Ä 8.05 (s, 2H), 7.74 (s, 4H), 7.16 (s, 4H), 7.11 (s, 4H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, MeOH -D4): ¦Ä 138.6, 134.1, 130.5, 127.4, 121.5.[1c]    S24 1,1,2,2 -tetrakis(4 -(1H-imidazol -1-yl)phenyl)ethene:  66% yield (394.4 mg); yellowish crystalline solid; 1H NMR (CDC l3, 400 MHz): ¦Ä 7.86 (s, 4H), 7.19 -7.27 (m, 24H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä 141.8, 139.9, 136.2, 135.4, 132.8, 130.7, 120.8, 117.9.[1d]     Figure  S31. 1H NMR spectrum of the substrate recorded in CDCl 3.

The phasepurity and morph ology ofthemater ialAg0@OB4Rwere explor edbypowd erX-ray diffraction (PXRD) and scan-ning electr onmicro scopy (SEM). The as-syn thesized materialAg0@OB4Rexhibit edfive charact eristic lattice plane (FCC) sig-nals[12b,d]ofsilver at2q/C2538.3 8,44.4 8,64.6 8,77.5 8,and81.6 8along with theprese nce oforganic barrel OB4R(Figur e2a)sig-nals. This observa tion supports that nostructur alintegrit yofthe barrelwas lost during the AgNPs synth esis. The surfac emorph ology was exam inedbyscan ning electr onmicro scopy(SEM) imagin g,which showe dgranu larsize particles (Fig-ure1a).Furthermo re,theenergy- disper sive X-ray spectros cop-ic(EDS) image ofAg0@OB4Rrevea led(Figure S27aintheSup-porting Informa tion) thepresen ceofsilver and other elementssuch asCandN.X-ray elemental mapp ing images (Fig-ureS27bintheSupporting Informa tion) indicat edthat theAgNP saredistrib uted hom ogeneously .[25a]Inaddition, silver NPbinding intheconfined spacewas veri-fied bythe poros itydifferenc efrom nitrog engas adsor ption /desor ptionexperiments .Asshown inFigure 2b,theN2adsorp-tions by OB4Rand Ag0@OB4Rat77Ka re55.6 and15.8 cm3g/C01,respect ively .Thesurface areas estimated bytheBrunauer¨CEm mett¨CT eller (BET) mode lare15.3 and 2.9m2g/C01forfree OB4Rand Ag0@OB4R,respectively .Thisobser vationsuggest sthatAgNP soccupy thesignifi cant fraction ofthecon-fined space ofthe organic barrel OB4R.Analysis using induc -tively coupled plasma mass spectromet ry (ICP-M S) ofAg0@OB4Rrevea ledthat thesilver loading ofthecomp osite isaroun d52wt%,which isaveryhigh silver loading foradis-crete organic cage compo und. Generally ,MNPs loading morethan 20wt%byany wet chemical meth odexperi ence agglom-eratio nasdescri bed prev iously intheliterature.[25a]Weperformed acontrol ledexperiment todistinguis hthein-fluence ofstructu ralfeatures such asshape and size oftheor-ganic barrel onthe precise control over AgNPs growth. Onthat occasion ,wetreated AgOT finmethano lwithtwo equiva -lents ofNaBH4intheabsence oforganic barrel (OB4R).Asdis-played inFigure S28a(intheSupp orting Inform ation), theTEMimage ofthe resulting black materia l(named assilver bulk,that is,Ag@bulk )showe dtheformation ofstructu re-less ag-glome rates. These outcomes furthe rindica tethat the metalbinding sites and the confined space ofthe molecula rbarrelplay crucial roles inthesize-c ontrolled nucle ation and stabil iza-tion oftiny AgNP s.

The organic barre lwasfinally used asamo-lecular vesse lforthecontrolled nucle ation ofsilver nanopar-ticles (AgNP s)with fine size tuning through bindin gofAgIions intheconfined space ofthebarrelfollowed byreduc-tion. Transmiss ionelectro nmicroscopy (TEM) analysi softheAg0@OB4Rcompo siterevealed that themean particl esizeis1.44/C60.16 nm. The composite materia lhasapprox imately52wt%silver loading .Thebarrel-sup ported ultrafine AgNPs[Ag0@OB4R]arefound tobeanefficient photo catalys tforfacile Ullmann -type aryl-aminat ioncoup ling ofhaloarenes atambie nttemperature without using anyadditi ves. The cata-lyst was stable forseveral cycles ofreuse without any ag-glome ration. The new compo siteAg0@OB4Rrepres ents thefirst example ofdiscrete organic barrel -suppor ted AgNPsemployed asaphotoca talyst inUllmann-typ ecoupli ngreac-tions atroom tempe rature.
